question.title: getting error as sun.misc.Unsafe cannot be resolved while modifying library

node.contents: i'm developing an android sdk for my project and for that i'm using google-http-java-client in sdk . i want to make some changes in google-http-java-client so that i can use it in my app . for instance i want to add some custom headers in com.google.api.client.http.HttpHeaders . For that i have extract the source code but im getting an error in com.google.common.primitives.UnsignedBytes as

astNode.text: i'm developing an android sdk for my project and for that i'm using google-http-java-client in sdk . i want to make some changes in google-http-java-client so that i can use it in my app . for instance i want to add some custom headers in com.google.api.client.http.HttpHeaders . For that i have extract the source code but im getting an error in com.google.common.primitives.UnsignedBytes as

node.contents: So is there any other way to modify this library ???

astNode.text: So is there any other way to modify this library ???

node.contents: @EJP Are you quite sure that sun.misc.Unsafe doesn't exist in Android? I would be extremely surprised. More likely, it just isn't in the default compilation classpath.

astNode.text: @EJP Are you quite sure that sun.misc.Unsafe doesn't exist in Android? I would be extremely surprised. More likely, it just isn't in the default compilation classpath.

node.contents: that means i can not use this library into my project ....

astNode.text: that means i can not use this library into my project ....

node.contents: @curious_mind: Sure you can, using it in compiled form is no problem at all and if you really need to use the sources, you just need to leave out the offending part. You could leave out the whole class `UnsignedBytes` unless you need it.

astNode.text: @curious_mind: Sure you can, using it in compiled form is no problem at all and if you really need to use the sources, you just need to leave out the offending part. You could leave out the whole class `UnsignedBytes` unless you need it.

node.contents: @EJP: You're wrong, nobody is relying on Unsafe. It's not him as it appears in the Guava library and they're not relying on it as they provide a fallback solution.

astNode.text: @EJP: You're wrong, nobody is relying on Unsafe. It's not him as it appears in the Guava library and they're not relying on it as they provide a fallback solution.

node.contents: @maaartinus That can only mean that somebody else is relying on it. Same remarks apply. Nothing wrong about it whatsoever.

astNode.text: @maaartinus That can only mean that somebody else is relying on it. Same remarks apply. Nothing wrong about it whatsoever.

node.contents: You are relying on things shippped with the Oracle/Sun JDK that aren't provided by Google. Short answer: don't do that. Long answer: see 'Why Developers Should Not Write Programs That Call 'sun' Packages'.

astNode.text: You are relying on things shippped with the Oracle/Sun JDK that aren't provided by Google. Short answer: don't do that. Long answer: see 'Why Developers Should Not Write Programs That Call 'sun' Packages'.

node.contents: Are you quite sure that sun.misc.Unsafe doesn't exist in Android? I would be extremely surprised. More likely, it just isn't in the default compilation classpath.

astNode.text: Are you quite sure that sun.misc.Unsafe doesn't exist in Android? I would be extremely surprised. More likely, it just isn't in the default compilation classpath.

node.contents: @Kevin Bourrillion: I'm not sure at all, it was just an assumption based on what I've heard. But based on my experience, removing the reference might be much faster than finding what to include in the classpath.

astNode.text: @Kevin Bourrillion: I'm not sure at all, it was just an assumption based on what I've heard. But based on my experience, removing the reference might be much faster than finding what to include in the classpath.

node.contents: Sure. The UnsafeComparator uses Unsafe which is not on the default classpath1 in android, but there's also the PureJavaComparator provided as a fallback. Removing the whole part dealing with Unsafe should suffice, as in getBestComparator() it gets looked up via its name and in case of an exception the fallback gets used.

astNode.text: Sure. The UnsafeComparator uses Unsafe which is not on the default classpath1 in android, but there's also the PureJavaComparator provided as a fallback. Removing the whole part dealing with Unsafe should suffice, as in getBestComparator() it gets looked up via its name and in case of an exception the fallback gets used.

node.contents: 1 I was thinking it doesn't exist in android, but I believe Kevin saying it does. Anyway, saying that it's not on the default classpath is surely correct (regardless of its existence).
